document.docAuthor: Oliveira, Luiz Fernando M. & Brescovit, Antonio D.
document.masterDocTitle: The spider genus Patrera Simon (Araneae: Dionycha, Anyphaeninae) in the Atlantic Forest biome, with the description of one new species from Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The spider genus Patrera Simon (Araneae: Dionycha, Anyphaeninae) in the Atlantic Forest biome, with the description of one new species from Brazil

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Programa de Pós-Graduação em Zoologia, Instituto de Biociências de São Paulo, Rua do Matão, 14, 05508 - 090, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, SP, Brazil. & Laboratório de Coleções Zoológicas, Instituto Butantan, Av. Vital Brasil, 1500, 05503 - 900, São Paulo, SP, Brazil.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anyphaena procera
Keyserling, 1891: 86
, figs 49–49a ( Syntypes male and female from Rio de Janeiro ( 22°54’10”S ; 43°12’28”W ),

subSubSection.paragraph:
Rio de Janeiro , Brazil , 7.I.1890 , Keyserling leg., deposited in BMNH 1890.7.1.613-614, examined. Lectotype male and paralectotype female here designated).
Teudis procerus : Petrunkevitch, 1911: 518
.
Aysha cinereovittata Mello-Leitão, 1945: 242
( partim , only the females MLP; males =
Iguarima censoria (Keyserling)
, see

Diagnosis. Males of
Patrera procera
can be distinguished from the remaining species by the characteristic tibial retrolateral apophysis wide, subrectangular, with a transverse fold at the tip, forming a conspicuous groove,

and by the conical dorsal tibial apophysis ( Figs 1D , 2B , 3E ) in the male palp. Females are diagnosed by their short, narrow epigynal lateral borders with lateral excavation at the internal borders and wide deep atrium in the epigynum ( Figs 2C , 3F ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1A–G.
Patrera procera (Keyserling, 1981)
. Male (IBSP 138902): A habitus, dorsal view; C left palp, ventral view; D same, retrolateral view; E same, dorsal view. Female (IBSP 138902): B habitus, dorsal view; F epigynum, ventral view; G epigynum, dorsal view. Abbreviations: A, atrium; dTA, dorsal tibial apophysis; E, embolus; LB, lateral borders; MA, median apophysis; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; T, tegulum. Scale bars: A, B 3.5mm; C 0.6mm; D 0.73mm; E 0.66mm; F 0.4mm; G 0.25mm.

FIGURE 2A–D.
Patrera procera ( Keyserling, 1891 )
. Male (MCN 10965): A left palp, ventral view; B same, retrolateral view. Female (MCN 3172): C epigynum, ventral view (arrow indicating the excavation at the lateral borders); D same, dorsal view. Abbreviations: A, atrium; CD, copulatory ducts; dTA, dorsal tibial apophysis; E, embolus; FD, fertilization ducts; H, hood; LB, lateral borders; MA, median apophysis; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; S, spermathecae; SR, seminal receptacles; T, tegulum. Scale bars: A–D 0.25mm.

FIGURE 3A–F.
Patrera procera ( Keyserling, 1891 )
. Male (IBSP 139486): A chelicerae, ventral view; B left palp, ventral view; C same, distal view; D same, ventral view; E same, retrolateral view. Female (IBSP 138902): F epigynum, ventral view (arrow indicating the excavation at the lateral borders). Abbreviations: A, atrium; CO, copulatory opening; dTA, dorsal tibial apophysis; E, embolus; LB, lateral borders; MA, median tibial apophysis; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; T, tegulum. Scale bars: A 0.3mm; B 0.4mm; C, F 0.2mm; D, E 0.1mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Male ( Lectotype , BMNH). Carapace orange brown, with orange paramedian stripes. Chelicerae brown yellowish, labium and endites orange. Sternum light orange, with dark borders. Legs orange. Abdomen dorsally brownish, ventrally cream ( Fig. 1A ). Total length 8.6, carapace length 3.5, width 2.65. Clypeus height 0.15. Eye diameters and interdistances: AME 0.11, ALE 0.20, PME 0.17, PLE 0.20; AME–AME 0.06, AME–ALE 0.08, PME–PME 0.21, PME–PLE 0.17, ALE–PLE 0.07. Chelicerae 2.3 long, four promarginal teeth, nine small retromarginal denticles ( Fig. 3A ). Leg measurements: leg I—femur 5.5/ patella 1.5/ tibia 6.1/ metatarsus 5.2/ tarsus 2.05/ total 20.35; II—4.85/ 1.3/ 5.25/ 4.6/ 1.9/ 17.9; III—3.1/ 1.05/ 2.5/ 3.4/ 1.0/ 11.05; IV—4.8/ 1.3/ 4.35/ 5.75/ 1.2/ 17.75. Leg spination: I—II—tibia v2-2-0, p1-1-1, r1-1-1, metatarsus v2-0-0, p1-1-0, r1-1-0; III—IV—tibia v2- 2-2, p1-1-1, r1-1-1, metatarsus v2-2-2, p1-1-1, r1-1-1. Abdomen: length 5.35, epigastric furrow 1.4 from tracheal spiracle, spiracle 2.3 from base of spinnerets. Palp: tibia as long as cymbium; tegulum oval; spermatic duct “Ushaped” ventrally; short distal tegular projection, close to the embolus apex; subdistal median apophysis, inverted “S-shaped”; embolus with median prolateral origin, thin, with broad base, slightly curved ( Figs 1C , 2A , 3B, C ).

Female ( Paralectotype BMNH). Coloration as in male, except dorsal area of the abdomen lighter ( Fig. 1B ). Total length 9.2, carapace length 3.8, width 2.8. Clypeus height 0.16. Eye diameters and interdistances: AME 0.11, ALE 0.20, PME 0.16, PLE 0.18; AME–AME 0.07, AME–ALE 0.06, PME–PME 0.22, PME–PLE 0.18, ALE–PLE 0.06. Chelicerae 1.67 long, five promarginal teeth, eight retromarginal denticles. Leg measurements: leg I—femur 4.8/ patella 1.55/ tibia 5.1/ metatarsus 4.1/ tarsus 2.1/ total 17.65; II—4.3/ 1.4/ 4.5/ 3.85/ 1.7/ 15.75; III—3.1/ 1.2/ 2.4/ 3.1/ 1.0/ 10.8; IV—4.6/ 1.4/ 4.1/ 5.0/ 5.0/ 1.3/ 16.4. Leg spination: I—tibia v2-2-0, p1-0-0, r1-0-0, metatarsus v2-0-0, p0, r0; II—tibia v2-2-0, p1-1-1, r0, metatarsus v2-0-0, p1-0-0, r0; III—IV—tibia v2-2-2, p1-1-1-, r1-1-1, metatarsos v2-2-2, p1-1-1, r1-1-1. Abdomen: length 5.7, epigastric furrow 1.55 from tracheal spiracle, spiracle 2.25 from base of spinnerets. Epigynum: lateral borders narrow, not distally joined; internally with long, coiled copulatory ducts; seminal receptacles in the proximal area of the copulatory ducts; oval spermathecae; fertilization ducts as long as the spermathecae, curved and basally inserted ( Figs 1F, G , 2C, D , 3F ).
Variation. Males (n=10): total length 7.4–9.2; carapace length 2.8–3.8; femur I length 3.8–5.2. Females (n=10): total length: 8.5–9.7; carapace length 3.3–3.6; femur I length 4.2–4.8.
Distribution . Northeast to southern Brazil , West Paraguay and Northeastern Argentina ( Fig. 27C ).
